text: Alfred Zinnemann (April 29, 1907 – March 14, 1997) was an Austrian Empire-born American movie director and producer. He won four Academy Awards for directing and producing movies. He also won a BAFTA Award and two Golden Globe Awards. His best known movies were The Search (1947), The Men (1950), High Noon (1952), From Here to Eternity (1953), Oklahoma! (1955), The Nun's Story (1959), A Man For All Seasons (1966), The Day of the Jackal (1973), and Julia (1977). His movies have received 65 Oscar nominations, winning 24. His parents were Austrian Jews.the London telegraph: "The music behind Hollywood's golden age – As the Proms pays tribute to Hollywood's golden age, Tim Robey looks at the composers who redefined the film score" By Tim Robey. August 24, 2013. He graduated with a law degree from the University of Vienna in 1927. He later studied at Ecole Technique de Photographie et Cinématographie in Paris to become a cameraman. Both of his parents were killed during the Holocaust. Zinnemann died of a heart attack in London, England on March 14, 1997 almost one month before his 90th birthday. ==References== Category:1907 births Category:1997 deaths Category:Academy Award winning directors Category:Golden Globe Award winning directors Category:BAFTA Award winning directors Category:Naturalized citizens of the United States Category:Deaths from myocardial infarction Category:Austrian movie directors Category:Austrian movie producers Category:Austrian Jews Category:American cinematographers Category:Movie directors from Los Angeles Category:Movie producers from Los Angeles Category:American Jews
title: Fred Zinnemann
